title: Amaranta Gómez Regalado
text:
Amaranta Gómez Regalado (born 1977) is a Mexican <a href="Muxe">Muxe</a> social anthropologist, political candidate, <a href="HIV">HIV</a> prevention activist, social researcher, columnist and promoter of <a href="pre-Columbian">pre-Columbian</a> indigenous cultural identity.
Biography.
Gómez was born in 1977 in a <a href="Zapotec%20civilization">Zapotec</a> village close to the border of <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> and adopted the name of Amaranta during adolescence, after reading "<a href="One%20Hundred%20Years%20of%20Solitude">One Hundred Years of Solitude</a>", the famous work of Colombian writer <a href="Gabriel%20Garc%C3%ADa%20M%C3%A1rquez">Gabriel García Márquez</a>.
During high school, Gómez Regalado studied languages and theater in <a href="Veracruz">Veracruz</a>. She then traveled to several states in southern Mexico as part of a <a href="transvestism">transvestism</a> show.
In October 2002, a car accident fractured her left arm to such an extent that it had to be amputated.
In 2015 she managed to change her <a href="gender%20identity">gender identity</a> on her birth certificate, which allowed her to change other official documents such as a passport. This was possible from the reforms approved by what was once the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Mexico%20City">Legislative Assembly of Mexico City</a> to allow people to legally change their gender identity in their birth certificate, through only an administrative procedure. (See <a href="LGBT%20rights%20in%20Mexico%23Gender%20identity%20and%20expression">LGBT rights in Mexico#Gender identity and expression</a>.)
She studied social anthropology at the <a href="Universidad%20Veracruzana">University of Veracruz</a> between 2011 and 2016. Her undergraduate thesis was titled "Guendaranaxhii: the Muxe community of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec and the emotional erotic relations".
Activism.
At the age of 25, she gained international prominence as a candidate for the <a href="M%C3%A9xico%20Posible">México Posible</a> party in the <a href="2003%20Mexican%20elections">2003 elections</a> to the <a href="Congress%20of%20Mexico">Federal Congress</a>. Her broad platform included calls for the decriminalization of marijuana and abortion. Regalado did not win a seat.
Recognition.
The <a href="Escuela%20Amaranta%20G%C3%B3mez%20Regalado">Escuela Amaranta Gómez Regalado</a> in Santiago, Chile is named for her.
